python.Definition: used for the purpose of in-code documentation
Python has no command for declaring a variable. A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it using an equal sign.
Must start with a letter or the underscore character, can't start with a number, can only contain alpha-numeric characters and underscores, are case-sensitive
The Python print statement is often used to output variables. To combine both text and a variable, Python uses the + character
Int, or integer, is a whole number, positive or negative, without decimals, of unlimited length
Float, or 'floating point number' is a number, positive or negative, containing one or more decimals
Complex numbers are written with a 'j' as the imaginary part
String literals in python are surrounded by either single quotation marks, or double quotation marks.Strings can be output to screen using the print function
Can be used with a string to ask a user for input
(+) used to add two numbers together
(-) used to subract a number from another
(*) used to multiply two numbers
(/) used to divide a number by another
(%) returns the remainder after division is completed
(==) Comparison operator used when two Term have the same value
(!=) Comparison operator used when two Term do not have the same value
Greater-than comparison operator that says one value is greater than another
Less-than comparison operator that says one value is less than the other
Greater-then or Equal-to operator says one value is greater than OR equal-to another
Less-than or Equal-to operator says one value is less than OR equal to the other
Logical operators are used to combine conditional statements
Logical operator that returns True if both statements are true
Logical operator that returns True if one of the statements is true
Logical operator that reverses the result. Returns False if the result is true
used to compare the objects, not if they are equal, but if they are actually the same object, with the same memory location
Identity operator that returns true if both variables are the same object
Identity operator that returns true if both variables are not the same object
test if a sequence is presented in an object
Membership operator that returns True if a sequence with the specified value is present in the object
Membership operator that returns True if a sequence with the specified value is not present in the object
a collection which is ordered and changeable. In Python lists are written with square brackets
You can loop through each list item by using a for loop

python.Term: Check if Item Exists in List
python.Definition: use the in keyword
Used to determine how many items a list has
used to add an item to the end of the list
used to add an item at the specified index
Removes the item with the specified value
removes the specified index, (or the last item if index is not specified)
removes the specified index or a complete list
Removes all the elements from the list but empty list itself still remains
Used to make a new list
Reverses the order of the list
Sorts the list alphabetically
Used in If statements: if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition
Used in If statements to catch anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions
a logical operator used to combine conditional statements
python.Example: if a > b and c > a: print('True')

python.Definition: can execute a set of statements as long as a condition is true
used in While loop, can stop the loop even if the while condition is true
used in While loop, can stop the current iteration, and continue with the next
loop is used for iterating (execute a set of statements, once for each item in a list) over a sequence (that is either a list, a tuple, a dictionary, a set, or a string)
loops through a set of code starting from 0 by default, incrementing by 1 (by default), and ending at a specified number.
A nested loop is a loop inside a loop. The 'inner loop' will be executed one time for each iteration of the 'outer loop'
A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called. You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function. It can return data as a result.

Information can be passed to functions as parameter. Parameters are specified after the function name, inside the parentheses. You can add as many parameters as you want, just separate them with a comma.

CSS.Definition: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. CSS describes how HTML elements are to be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media
points to the HTML element you want to style
includes a CSS property name and a value, separated by a colon. A CSS declaration always ends with a semicolon, and declaration blocks are surrounded by curly braces.
(#) The id selector uses the id attribute of an HTML element to select a specific element. The id of an element should be unique within a page, so the id selector is used to select one unique element
The class selector selects elements with a specific class attribute. To select elements with a specific class, write a period (.) character, followed by the name of the class.
(/* */) Comments are used to explain the code, and may help when you edit the source code at a later date. Comments are ignored by browsers
set the background color for HTML elements
set the text-color for an HTML element
sets properties of border lines for HTML elements
a color can be specified as an RGB value, using this formula: rgb(red, green, blue). Each parameter (red, green, and blue) defines the intensity of the color between 0 and 255.
In HTML, a color can be specified using a hexadecimal value in the form: #rrggbb
a color can be specified using hue, saturation, and lightness (HSL) in the form: hsl(hue, saturation, lightness)
specifies an image to use as the background of an element. By default, the image is repeated so it covers the entire element
used to repeat background image only horizontally
sets the background image so that it only is displayed once (not repeated)
Sets whether a background image is fixed or scrolls with the rest of the page
Specifies where the background image(s) is/are positioned
Sets the starting position of a background image
Sets how a background image will be repeated
Specifies the size of the background image(s)
Sets all the bottom border properties in one declaration. Each border side has their own declaration (top, bottom, left, right)
Sets all the four border-radius properties for rounded corners
Sets the width of the four borders (can be used on seperate border sides as well)
used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders
You can set the margin property to auto to horizontally center the element within its container
used to generate space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders
sets the height of an element
sets the width of an element
sets the maximum height or width that an element can be
Sets the minimum height or width of an element
The CSS box model is essentially a box that wraps around every HTML element. It consists of: margins, borders, padding, and the actual content
An outline is a line that is drawn around elements, OUTSIDE the borders, to make the element 'stand out'.Style, Color, Width, and Offset properties can be assigned to it.
Sets the color of text
Specifies the text direction/writing direction
Increases or decreases the space between characters in a text
Specifies the horizontal alignment of text
Specifies how overflowed content that is not displayed should be signaled to the user
Sets the vertical alignment of an element
generic family - a group of font families with a similar look (like 'Serif' or 'Monospace'). font family - a specific font family (like 'Times New Roman' or 'Arial')
sets font properties. Properties can include: -family, -size, -style, -variant, and -weight
have four states: link, visited, hover and active. Each state can be styled using any CSS property

HTML.Definition: HTML elements are the building blocks of HTML pages
HTML elements are represented by tags
Everything between the opening/closing tags is what appears on screen
Root element of an HTML page, everything is contained within these tags
The element that contains meta info about the document

HTML.Definiton: Element that specifies a title for the document

HTML.Definition: Element containing the visible page content
Largest heading element you can create
Smallest heading element you can create
HTML tag used to create a paragraph element, also called the opening tag
Closing tag to the paragraph element - requires the / to work

HTML.Definiton: Line break - if you want a line break without starting a new paragraph

HTML.Definition: the location of the image to display

HTML.Definiton: attribute specifies alternative text to be used when an image cannot be displayed

HTML.Definition: tag to create a button element
tag to create an unordered list element
tag to create an ordered list element

HTML.Defintion: tag to create a list element inside either ul or ol elements

HTML.Definition: Specifies a unique id for an element
